key_points: Congressional Democrats, led by House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, begin efforts to remove President Donald Trump from office, potentially making him the first president to be impeached twice.
A House vote on articles of impeachment is expected as early as Wednesday.
The drive to remove Trump follows the storming of the Capitol by his supporters.
A resolution will be voted on Tuesday to urge Vice President Mike Pence and Cabinet officials to invoke the 25th Amendment, with a 24-hour deadline before moving toward impeachment.
The 25th Amendment allows the vice president and the Cabinet to remove a president deemed unfit.
Several judges and Attorney General William Barr have found no evidence of widespread election fraud as claimed by Trump.
Corporate America begins to withhold campaign contributions from lawmakers who supported challenges to Biden's Electoral College win.
Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell indicates an impeachment trial could not begin before Inauguration Day.
Republicans argue impeachment would be divisive, but some are open to considering it.
The possibility of impeachment raises questions about its impact on the start of President-elect Joe Biden's term.
spokespersons: Kim Keck (CEO and President, Blue Cross Blue Shield Association)
Candi Wolff (Head of Global Government Affairs, Citigroup)
